Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause/privity and foreseeability principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: - Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause/privity and foreseeability principles).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The opinion is the classic source for the principle that negligence is relational and that duty (and thus liability) extends only to those within the foreseeable zone of risk, which is a core component of proximate cause analysis. Cardozo explicitly rejects liability where the defendant’s conduct did not create an apparent risk to the particular plaintiff, emphasizing foreseeability and the need for a duty owed to that plaintiff. This squarely supports citing Palsgraf for proximate cause and foreseeability principles (often analogized to a privity-like limitation of duty).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all. Nothing in the situation gave notice that the falling package had in it the potency of peril to persons thus removed… The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.”

Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (no.raw_text: Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (notice pleading principles)
Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (no.proposition: - Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (notice pleading principles);
Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (no.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates and applies the Federal Rules’ “notice pleading” standard, emphasizing that a complaint need only contain a short and plain statement giving fair notice and should not be dismissed unless no set of facts could entitle the plaintiff to relief. It also contrasts this simplified approach with older, more technical pleading requirements. Thus, Conley directly supports the proposition that it is authority for notice pleading principles.
Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41 (1957) (no.relevant_excerpt: “In appraising the sufficiency of the complaint we follow, of course, the accepted rule that a complaint should not be dismissed for failure to state a claim unless it appears beyond doubt that the plaintiff can prove no set of facts in support of his claim which would entitle him to relief. … The decisive answer to this is that the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure do not require a claimant to set out in detail the facts upon which he bases his claim. To the contrary, all the Rules require is ‘a short and plain statement of the claim’ that will give the defendant fair notice of what the plaintiff’s claim is and the grounds upon which it rests.”

Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544.raw_text: Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544 (2007)
Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544.proposition: - Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544 (2007);
Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544.support_reasoning: The 'proposition' given is just the bare citation to Twombly with no accompanying legal principle or statement of law. Without a specific proposition (e.g., about pleading standards or plausibility), it is impossible to determine whether the opinion supports it. The case clearly stands for the plausibility pleading standard, but since no substantive proposition is articulated, I cannot say it supports the claimed proposition as stated.
Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544.relevant_excerpt: In applying these general standards to a § 1 claim, we hold that stating such a claim requires a complaint with enough factual matter (taken as true) to suggest that an agreement was made. Asking for plausible grounds to infer an agreement does not impose a probability requirement at the pleading stage; it simply calls for enough fact to raise a reasonable expectation that discovery will reveal evidence of illegal agreement.

Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662 (2009).support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is not actually stated; it is just the case name and citation with no legal principle attached. Without a specific legal proposition (e.g., about pleading standards, plausibility, or qualified immunity), it is impossible to determine whether the opinion supports it. The provided excerpt concerns Justice Breyer’s dissent about case-management tools and does not itself establish a clear, standalone rule matching any articulated proposition.
Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662 (2009).relevant_excerpt: "I write separately to point out that, like the Court, I believe it important to prevent unwarranted litigation from interfering with 'the proper execution of the work of the Government.' Ante, at 685. But I cannot find in that need adequate justification for the Court’s interpretation of Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U. S. 544 (2007), and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8."

Hughes v. Boston, 374 Mass. 160 (1978) (.case_name: Dane v. Board of Registrars of Voters of Concord
Hughes v. Boston, 374 Mass. 160 (1978) (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns voter registration, domicile, and the authority of registrars and courts under the Massachusetts election laws; it does not address municipal or landowner tort duties, premises liability, or related duty-of-care principles. Citing Hughes v. Boston for “municipal/landowner duty principles” is therefore inaccurate, as the case’s holdings are about voting rights, domicile of prisoners, and procedural obligations of registrars, not duties of municipalities as landowners.
Hughes v. Boston, 374 Mass. 160 (1978) (.relevant_excerpt: “The issue with which we are presently faced, however, is whether a person domiciled in one place and who is then sentenced to a correctional institution in another city or town has the capacity to acquire a new domicil for voting purposes in the place of his incarceration.”

Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985.raw_text: Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985) (reasonable care and foreseeability)
Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985.proposition: - Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985) (reasonable care and foreseeability)*
Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is from a dissent focused on evidentiary discretion and the collateral-source rule, not on reasonable care or foreseeability. Nothing in this text discusses the standard of reasonable care, duty, or foreseeability in negligence. If Olsen contains such a discussion, it is in another portion of the opinion, not in the excerpt provided, so based on this text alone it does not support the stated proposition.
Olsen v. Commonwealth, 396 Mass. 9 (1985.relevant_excerpt: Collateral source evidence has been deemed irrelevant because “the receipts from the outside source do not go to reduce the defendant’s liability; yet jurors might be led by the irrelevancy to consider plaintiffs’ claims unimportant or trivial or to refuse plaintiffs’ verdicts or reduce them, believing that otherwise there would be unjust double recovery.” Goldstein v. Gontarz, 364 Mass. 800, 809 (1974). Exceptions to any general rule should be cautiously considered, lest the exceptions swallow the rule.

McGrail v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not McGrail v. Stop & Shop, a premises-liability slip-and-fall case; it is Peckham v. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition regarding retail-store slip-and-fall law.
McGrail v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff, John M. Peckham, III, appeals from a judgment for the defendant newspaper, the Boston Herald (Herald), on Peckham’s tort claim of public disclosure of private facts under G. L. c. 214, § 1B. The judge correctly allowed the Herald’s motion for summary judgment..."

Mandile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.case_name: Commissioner of Revenue v. Houghton Mifflin Co.
Mandile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Mandile v. Stop & Shop; it is a Massachusetts tax case about whether Houghton Mifflin qualifies as a “manufacturing corporation” for investment tax credit purposes. It does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall incidents, or rules on notice or constructive notice in store cases. Therefore, it does not support the proposition concerning notice and constructive notice in store slip-and-fall cases.
Mandile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.relevant_excerpt: A “manufacturing corporation” is defined by G. L. c. 63, § 38C, as a corporation “engaged in manufacturing.” This “less than illuminating” definition, William F. Sullivan & Co. v. Commissioner of Revenue, 413 Mass. 576, 579 (1992), combined with the desirability of the classification, has spawned a great body of caselaw, in which we have concluded that “[t]he words ‘engaged in manufacturing’ as used in [G. L. c. 63, § 38C,] ... are words of flexible meaning.”
